ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:
Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: How to calculate fertility and mortality rates, how to calculate life table values, the history of demographic theories, current demographic transitions. We answered questions about why fertility rates are so low in developed countries, the relationship between fertility and mortality rates, and migration patterns.
How to view issues from a sociological/demographer's perspective.
I learned about how population dynamics affect our economy and natural resources, as well as world events. I also learned how to conduct a research project.

Demographic theory (fertility/mortality/age/migration/urban transiton) and why it matters to everyone living in the world today. I especially enjoyed the module in demographic theory and the age transition.
I learned more about demographic trends and how populations change over time.
I mainly learned from the content of the course. The topics that were newest to me were age and Urbanicity.

Survey of demography theory, concepts, and methods. Calculating descriptive statistics like life expectancy and mortality rates. Learned how to create and conduct research projects. Overall also a great introduction to sociology and its subfields.
I learned more about demographic studies and interesting facts and statistics

I learned a great deal about the demographics of populations, including fertility, health and mortality, lifespan/longevity, migration trends, etc. Class material focused mostly on the US, but examples from other countries featured as well.
I learnt more about the discipline of sociology and the different population transitions that are applicable in our world today.

I learned so much about the field of demography and about how to approach sociological research in general. All the different demographic trends we learned about came together in the end and it just gave me a much better understanding about how we live as people.
the basics of population studies, how to read and write sociological work

This course gives a pretty basic outline to demography and population studies. We reviewed different population transitions, and methods/information demographers focus on. Some of the readings include recent research on prevalent issues in demography (like how COVID affects different subgroups, racial differences in healthcare, etc).
general overview of main topics that demographers study (age, urbanization, migration, fertility)

This course provided an in-depth overview of demography, combining textbook readings with academic papers an in-class lectures. I learned about the ways demographers approach the study of human populations and population change, the relevance of demography for understanding important contemporary trends and  and future trajectories, and the ways that demographers conceptualize and calculate population shapes, sizes, and shifts. I gained skills reading academic papers, conducting research, and collaborating with others on an academic project .

I learned about all of the major demographic transitions, from fertility, to age, to mortality, to talking about broad demographic trends in urban areas, to racial trends, ethnicity-based trends... I could go on. We learned how to calculate mortality rates (AAMR) and complete a life table (which is apparently an actuarial duty!). We studied some of the major philosophers' ideas about population growth and decline and critically discussed them. We talked about marriage and its future. I also learned how to write a literature review.

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: A strength of this course was in the interesting subject matter and Professor Zang's knowledge on it. Several of the papers presented in the class were co-authored by Professor Zang and she was very available to answer questions during lectures. A weakness was the volume of required readings for section, though those were diminished over the course of the semester. I also thought the length of class during the project presentations was too long. The professor and TAs for this class were very accommodating, largely because this was a newer course and it was online.
1 lecture and 1 lab per week
The course was very short and somewhat rushed in a sense. We had one class a week, which was confusing for me.

Professor Zang did an excellent job making the material accessible and interesting to learn. I appreciated how much she engaged the class with questions. My only suggestion would be to provide students with more guidance on how to conduct research projects and write research papers.

Strengths: Professor Zang is great, exams are not too hard (though I didn't do well on the first one, we got to hand in corrections for credit), all the materials including the final project is enjoyable. Above, a SC credit!
Weaknesses: there's no incentives to read the paper she assigns. As a result, I wish that there are reading quizzes of some sort so that a) we can be more engaged and b) the final project doesn't have to count for 50% of the final grade.

A strength is that it covers a variety of topics in sociology/population studies each week. There was a 20 page paper due by the end of term, but the professor included project presentations in the course structure to make sure that students were working on their project throughout the semester.
I enjoyed the content of the course and found the lectures more helpful than the discussion sections.

I didn't find this course to be that engaging. I thought our discussion sections were not very helpful, but more of a reiteration of the readings. The lectures were difficult to follow and went very quickly. One strength was the formatting of the exams and final paper. I really enjoyed those as the basis for our evaluation.

Strengths: covered so many aspects of demography, gave me foundational knowledge on demographic calculations and theories, professor was very kind and willing to answer questions. Weaknesses: the class could sometimes go too fast to fully absorb the information on the slides. Also, readings from the textbook were very long and dense without too much substantial content.
Strong on all cylinders no weaknesses

Strengths included that the class could be approached from a variety of different perspectives: history, science, politics, etc. There were a variety of students, both STEM and social science, in the class which really helped create productive discussions.

The course was very engaging since the professor constantly engaged the class in questions and discussions. For the final project, we were given a great deal of autonomy to explore what we were interested in.

Strengths: really interesting material, Professor Zang is so incredibly knowledgeable and a wonderful lecturer, good discussion sections to clarify anything you're confused about, material correlates with readings really well which gives you a good chance to engage with everything 

Weaknesses: the only thing I can think of was at times the reading load was a bit heavy but Professor Zang was super understanding and adjusted accordingly

The best thing about this course was how focused Professor Zang was on helping students engage with the material. She was very receptive to feedback and was always looking for the best way to help us learn.

A big strength of the course was its breadth -- it was a pretty good intro into the field of demography if you had never learned about it before (I hadn't). My TF was super helpful for the final project, and the final project was actually a really great opportunity to work with other students in the class (it's a pretty sizable undertaking, so I would recommend doing it as a group). One challenge was the calculation based content like life tables, which are very integral to the field but require a lot of practice to get the hang of. At first, there wasn't enough guidance on that but Prof Zang made sure to slow down.

Strengths: lecture moves very quickly, topics were interesting and had real world examples 

Weaknesses: too much reading (though you could get by in the class without ever doing it)

This course was very well organized, making it easy to follow along with the themes and concepts being discussed. Discussion sections did an excellent job of reinforcing knowledge gained during lectures, and academic readings helped to supplement the class's textbook with real-world examples of demographic work. With the combination of academic papers and textbook chapters, occasionally the reading load for the course felt heavy. Additionally, lectures often covered many of the same subjects which had been discussed in the assigned textbook readings. I think that giving more clear expectations of what students should look for in readings would be helpful here, and having a more clear distinction between lectures and textbook work. Lectures could move very quickly, which was mad manageable by the fact that lecture slides were available on Canvas. However, the more quantitative concepts learned were more difficult to understand from only the slides, and I think that devoting more external resources to understand them would be helpful as well. The course would also benefit from a more clear outlining of expectations for student quantitative and scientific knowledge. Many students came from different academic backgrounds, and it was sometimes unclear how much we were expected to know or learn about the math or science underlying certain demographic concepts.

Strengths: fantastic professor with equally as fantastic lecturing. Wonderfully resplendent slides with lots of information, very interesting content, and not too many assignments.
Weaknesses: while the lectures were very engaging, they were very dense. Without having implemented the recording halfway through the semester, I would have been unable to learn adequately. The exams were okay -- the first one was rough, because two questions wrong = 130/150, which can tank a grade very fast. They did provide a bonus points opportunity, which was very generous and greatly appreciated. The lectures were simply very, very fast. And the readings -- very long. Like, really long. Very relevant, but super super long. Final project was also a huge undertaking, with not a whole lot of guidance, especially for an introductory course. Assumed statistics background if choosing to do a quantitative project.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I liked that there was only one lecture a week and that the other time was dedicated to discussion sections. The lecture was fairly small so it was also very engaging. Students answered questions and could engage the professor.
I appreciated the smaller lecture size that allowed for class engagement. Additionally, holding Zoom office hours made attending quite convenient.
Overall worked pretty well
there were no weaknesses or strengths regarding covid.
Everything succeeded like all the classes

I felt Prof Zang did a good job in stimulating class discussion even over Zoom, as did our TAs during the discussion section. She kept switching up the people she called on and had plenty of opportunities for participation.
The live lectures were very conducive to virtual engagement since I was able to ask questions to clarify my understanding.
Recorded lectures were a very effective virtual learning tool.

The smaller lecture size was helpful for COVID because it made it more engaging for students. A lot of people had their cameras on, and Prof Zang sometimes cold called (nothing intense, just to see what people thought) so I was usually pretty engaged with the lecture. The group project was also a good way to connect with students (me and the other three members of my group were remote for the semester), so that was really nice.
breakout rooms in section worked well for facilitating student discussion

The class made good use of virtual technology like Canvas and Zoom to keep lectures and discussion sections accessible and engaging. One way that virtual practices could have been improved is by saving lecture recordings for all students to access, with an agreement not to share personal information from those recordings with others.
The discussion section seemed kind of ... pointless? We reviewed some of the secondary readings, but those never came to play in the exams.

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Yes. The course was interesting and not too challenging. The final project was really intellectually stimulating and an opportunity to practice research skills.
Yes. If you are going into the social sciences this is a great class for the foundations of population studies.
Sure. It is a good way to begin thinking about  populations and the interactions, behaviors, differences among them.

Yes! Professor Zang did an excellent job teaching the class. I was also quite interested in the subject matter. Prior to taking this course, I hadn't realized just how intrinsic population dynamics were to our social institutions. It was truly fascinating to learn about it.  I also appreciated getting exposure to the scientific writing process.
It's an easy SC credit with quite a bit of writing towards the end of semester (though not bad at all). Definitely would recommend to all majors.
Yes, it's a good overview of population studies and the content learned in this course is applicable to a variety of fields.
I would recommend this course if you are interested in learning more about population trends.
If a student was looking for a science credit that wasn't hard science, I might recommend it. But I would note the weaknesses in the lecture style and discussion sections.

Yes if you're interested in sociology or what a science credit that's more applicable to the social sciences! I think it's also pretty unique among introductory social science classes as being more exam-based, as well as having most of the readings be from a demography textbook and papers- if you're not a fan of that work style I would not recommend it.
Yes!! Excellent professor & TAs, and interesting content
Yes because it was a low stress class with no homework and a not bad final project and 2 tests

As a social science student looking for an easy Science credit, I found this class super-helpful and interesting, but I'd recommend it even if you're not looking to fulfill the Sc requirement. Fascinating topics every week and a friendly professor.
Yes, highly! Population studies is such a fascinating topic, and the course introduces it in a way that makes me want to go deeper into the topic.

I would recommend this course to another student because of Professor Zang. She was so accessible all the time and very accommodating. Plus, the material is super interesting and not too hard to understand especially for someone like me who knew nothing about sociology or demography before this.
I would definitely recommend this course to another student. This class was accessible, engaging, and highly informative.

For sure! Especially if you're a humanities person looking for a science credit. The content covered was pretty interesting and good to know in any field. There were some kinks that needed to be worked out because this was the first year teaching the course, but Prof Zang and the TFs were super understanding and did a great job. I'm sure this class will be even better in person.

Definitely! It was a great introduction to population studies, and I learned a lot of general information related to demography. Although the first exam was somewhat difficult due to the time constraint and the number of calculations, the second exam was much more doable, and Professor Zang even gave us extra credit opportunities after hearing students' concerns regarding the first exam. The final paper took a long time, but Professor Zang was more than willing to review our topic with us and help us out along the way. In general, the class is not too stressful and is great if you plan on majoring in sociology or would like to take a Sc credit related to the humanities.
Yes, it is a great science gut and I learned some pretty interesting information along the way

I would recommend this course to all students, because the field of demography has relevance for everyone. Although we learned not to believe that "demography is destiny", the dynamics and characteristics of human populations are connected to everything else in society. This is a course that should be attractive to both STEM and Social Science oriented students, and students should anticipate a variety of readings, participatory lectures and sections. Most importantly, students should be ready to actively apply the concepts they learn to the world around them.

Sure. If you have any remote interest in sociology or the study of human behavior, this would be a great starting point. A lot of the concepts are intuitive, but in this class they're laid out in terminology and a textbook, and lectures, too. I left the class each day on a high, since the lectures were just that good. Professor Zang is incredibly engaging, and I'd love to hear her talk about demography all day long. She puts a picture of her dog on screen when it's time for questions. The exams aren't difficult per se, they're just difficult to score well, because even getting 2 questions wrong can give you a B. So tread carefully. And while a 20 page paper might seem like a lot, as a group project, it's not too bad. Just be prepared for a steady stream of work and keep up!

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: Weekly virtual discussion sections
Live virtual lecture and discussion section with TF
We had one live, virtual lecture per week, as well as a discussion section.
live lecture + section
We had live virtual lectures once a week, and also live discussion sections once a week.
Live lectures that were eventually recorded.
We had a lecture once a week and section another day of the week
Classes had a weekly live lecture and a weekly discussion seminar.
NIL
live virtual lecture with live discussion sections
Live virtual lecture and virtual discussion section

One weekly session was a lecture (started recording near the end of the semester). The other session (instead of another lecture day) was a section with one of the TFs, where we discussed content covered in lecture.
Half of the classes consisted of pure lectures, and the other half consisted of pure discussion sections.
lecture was recorded
Virtual discussion sections
When I  could not attend class, I  would watch recored lectures.
Our Tuesday class was a live virtual lecture, and the Thursday class session was a discussion section with one of the TFs.
